Reviews.Title: “3 L: location, location, location!”
Reviews.Author: Konstantin T
Reviews.Content: Main idea was trip to Vatican city and area around. That is the most best location if you have the same task. You need just cross only one street to appear on St.Peter sq. Rooms are veeeeeeeeery small and atmosphere like in monastery. Hotel have the world smallest elevator :)) Tips for travellers: 1. Taxi from Termini to hotel cost us €15 plus €2 as a tips cos we get a very funny driver. 2. Room wifi is only for one device, so try to use other room wifi to be online, like login: 211, pass: paolovi211, try 212, 213 etc :))

Reviews.Title: “St Peters on your doorstep”
Reviews.Author: DougCapeTown
Reviews.Content: I spent two nights at this hotel a couple years ago on a business trip, I really wanted to attend mass there on Sunday morning and got my wish. It is an old converted Abby so the rooms are really small with single beds. Being an Architect I was impressed with the restoration of the old building and delighted with the detail of the decor and furnishings. The service is top drawer and the restaurant is exquisite......if you are on business and need some privacy and enjoy luxury, then this is the place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “As close to St. Peter's as you can get!”
Reviews.Author: Hal013
Reviews.Content: The staff was amazingly pleasant and helpful. Really incredible! The location is superb. The food is good. The rooms are very efficient, but small. Very nice place

Reviews.Title: “top location, fantastic staff”
Reviews.Author: MacFfy
Reviews.Content: Location of this hotel for any visitors to the Vatican, and Rome in general. We stayed in the smallest room with a small bed and we were still very comfortable and didn't feel squashed. We were in the first room next to reception and were initially concerned about noise from the reception. We needn't have worried as the hotel was incredibly quite and peaceful. We couldn't even hear the phones ringing! The staff were absolutely excellent - helpful and accommodating. As a lesbian couple sharing a bed we were concerned about the type of reception we might get when checking into a hotel which appears to have religious persuasions. I'm delighted to report it was not at all a problem and not an eye lid was batted. We had a glorious two days there and are already hoping for a return trip. I cannot fault this hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Hidden Gem in Rome”
Reviews.Author: serving4theking_11
Reviews.Content: We didn't use the hotel, but we did have a private dinner and terrace reception here at the Paolo VI so this review concerns the dinner and reception, not an overnight stay. I'm leaving this review because the terrace at Paolo VI is maybe one of the hidden gems of Rome. It provides a beautiful private view of the Basilica dome and St. Peter's square. We were given private use of the terrace for over an hour. It should be mentioned that the picture of the terrace is a little misleading because the majority of the terrace is blocked off because it is property of the Augustinian monks and we were only given access to that portion for 5-10 minutes to snap some beautiful photos. No big issue there though. The manager, Marina, provided great communication prior to the event, and even let us know when the sunset time was for that evening for optimum picture-taking. The terrace reception was great with prosecco and a bartender and everything. Then we had dinner in the Bernini room. A four-course meal with their private chef. It began with stuffed artichokes, then we had risotto on a parmesian crust, followed by a very nice beef filet with a special sauce, and finished with a chocolate cake with raspberries. All of the service staff were amazing, and our evening was near perfect. Thank you Paolo VI.

Reviews.Title: “Beauty, Serenity, & Charm”
Reviews.Author: JWJ1981
Reviews.Content: It's always a pleasure to return to the Residenza! In the busy and large city of Rome, away from the crowds of the Spanish Steps, sits a beautiful boutique hotel, in a former monastary property. Completely renovated, the hotel features all the luxuries of top hotels, without sacrificing the hospitality and charm that one would expect of a hotel bearing the name of Paul VI. The rooms are beautifully maintained, clean, and have great views. The terrace features one of the most beautiful views in the city. Wifi is available in the rooms. The staff is most kind and breakfast is very good. I would not hesitate to reccomend this hotel. To the managment, I'd like to specifically recognize the kind and helpful assistance of Nicolleta. Grazie Mille!

Reviews.Title: “The very Best, Perfect Hotel and Staff”
Reviews.Author: owl64
Reviews.Content: We almost did not go to this hotel from reading other reviews, what a mistake that would have been. We could not fault the service we received from this place. We booked a suite, when we arrived the suite over looked the Vatican perfect view to wake up to. A very warm and welcoming hotel, all of the staff where helpful and there to help the guests. The hotel arranged a transfer from the airport to hotel and back again, a very good service. Breakfast was continental but a very full table with lots to pick from. The roof terrace is small but enough for the number of rooms this hotel has. We visited for our Anniversary and where able to arrange a meal on the one evening, the chef was second to none, rounded off the evening very well. We will recommend this hotel to all. Okay the standard rooms may be smaller than the suite we had, but hey you get what you pay for, and to be honest to be this close to St Peter's is worth any room, and to get such a perfect hotel, staff and location I would compromise on room size if I had to. At sometime we will be back, how could you not visit this beautiful city again.

Reviews.Title: “Lived in Rome; visited dozens of times; best hotel yet for my purposes”
Reviews.Author: BobinOmaha
Reviews.Content: This was opened by the Vatican in 2000 and is exactly across the street from the columns of St. Peters Square and directly opposite the Papal Palace. Since the hotel occupies the 4th and 5th floor of the building you can look right into the papal floor of the palace opposite. 3 minutes from St. Peters and 6 minutes inside if you have to go through security in the early morning. The hotel is small (about 40 rooms), the rooms are small, the included breakfast is great and the walk to the Vatican Museums is about 10 minutes. I almost hate to write a review for fear that more people will discover it.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect location overlooking St. Peter's Square!!”
Reviews.Author: dentist62
Reviews.Content: Very secure hotel right next to the Square. Basic but comfortable accommodations, the standard room is rather small. The staff is amazingly helpful and friendly. Breakfast had a good assortment but lukewarm, scrambled eggs. The terrace was a fantastic place to sit in the evening after a long day of sightseeing - to have a glass of wine and watch the sun setting over the Basilica was delightful! The rooms are expensive but you are paying for the proximity to the Vatican.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel, great location”
Reviews.Author: CrodoBeaver
Reviews.Content: Everything written about the hotel by other visitors is correct : the staff is fantastic, extremely helpful and polite and always smiling (which is not always the case in hotels in Italy). The atmosphere of the hotel is personal, quiet, and you won't be bumping into lots of tourists as it is a small hotel. Everything is neat and clean, the breakfast was varied with fruits, cold meat, eggs, bacon, etc. We particularly loved the terrasse which is indeed quite small but has enough tables and chairs for everybody (and not just one table with 2 chairs like it was previously reported). The airco system worked very well, and althought our room was on the street side we did not hear any noise at all (Vatican is rather quiet in the evening, no wild parties in St Peters ;-) It was great in the evening to go sit at the terrasse for a last drink before returning to our room. We also had Sunday morning was also very surprising when we realised we could hear the choir of St Peter when sitting on the terrasse, a real pleasure ! On the down side the standard bedroom we had was indeed very small and so was the bathroom. For a weekend it's ok but I would struggle to stay in such a small room for more then 2 nights. To summarize, the hotel is perfect for people who like small quiet and private hotels, and don't mind small rooms !

Reviews.Title: “Good if you are a nun..”
Reviews.Author: vcjf
Reviews.Content: This is a small pension up on a top floor in an apartment building opposite St. Peter's Basilica. Quiet, with no actual livingroom, the rooms have only small showers, and you can hear the street below if you open the windows. The most unfair thing is that they have a tiny balcony with two tables which they show in a way that looks like they have this enormous rooftop terrace. Nice view I suppose, but it isn't even their property. Rather misleading, not a real hotel. Good breakfast. Rather spartan.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely”
Reviews.Author: crmyer
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the hotel for two nights as headed off for the hills of Umbria. The hotel is lovely and in a great location. It is unusual in that it occupies the upper floors of a building housing Vatican offices. The rooms are very well appointed but small. The staff is very helpful and the hotel is very clean. We totally enjoyed staying there.

Reviews.Title: “Very good hotel, excellent location, tight rooms”
Reviews.Author: Drumas
Reviews.Content: This is a very good hotel. Staff is very helpful all the time and even like to talk to you even if you do not speak Italian. The location is excellent. It is simply aside Saint Peter's Church in the Vatican City. Rome does not have a good subway (it is very dirt and covers only a small fraction of the city), but the hotel is reasonably near subway and train stations. It also has a lot of bus lines that reach all parts of the city nearby. And you can easily go to downtown and historic sites by foot. As Rome is a lovely city to walk around, this matched to our purposes during the visitation. Rooms a little bit tight. They are really tighter if you book a French bed room. We did know Frech bed was so narrow and we did change to a Junior Suite the second night of our stay. The staff provided us the solution with no problem with a small and reasonable additional charge. Even so, the other room was a little bit tight if you have big cases. We had a small problem with the water temperature. It oscilated and we had to be a little bit patient until its temperature stabilized. But this was not annoying to such a point of not recommending Paolo VI. It is still a good hotel. The breakfast is North-American style and is very good. I recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Great location”
Reviews.Author: DrGuinness
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for two nights recently. The hotel is on the upper levels of a shared building which is very quiet. There's enough signage to guide you through, but not really a great presence in the downstairs area. Staff were very pleasant and all spoke English thankfully (since I didn't know much Italian). People have commented that the rooms are small, which is true, however it was rather adequate. There was a big enough bed, a small desk and average bathroom facilities. Having been an old monastery, it was just enough for one person. The bathroom was clean, but the rug in the bedroom was a little bit tired. Breakfast was a self-service buffet included in the price, and had the usual fare of continental, and some eggs and bacon in a chaffing dish. From the front door, it's only a few steps away from the Vatican, so the location is excellent. One let down was the hotel restaurant was only open for breakfast during the quiet season (winter) so you'll need to find somewhere else around the area for dinner if you're going off-peak.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect location, very pleasant hotel & staff”
Reviews.Author: aitenshi
Reviews.Content: This hotel is perfectly located as it is close to St. Peter's Square. I counted my steps from the gate of this hotel to the closest pillar in St. Peter's Square, it took me 20 steps and I have short legs, this would be less for someone with bigger steps. There is a lovely rooftop garden that is open from 4pm until midnight where you can have a drink and take in the view of St. Peter's Basilica and the Pope's chambers. The ambiance of the hotel is charming, calming and does not feel like a hotel at all. There is no hustle and bustle of luggages & tourists. When you enter the lift and get to reception you feel that you have entered a quiet realm like that of a museum but then you hear beautiful classical music playing through the sound system and are warmly greeted by friendly reception staff. This hotel is worth staying at if you are interested in being at the doorstep of St. Peter's basilica. If you want a quiet and extremely clean place to stay without ever bumping into more than 3 hotel guests at once then this is the place to stay. The hotel also provides free internet with a laptop to use. The buffet breakfast is located on the top floor in the Bernini room which is tastefully decorated.

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievable location right next to the Vatican”
Reviews.Author: NDLex
Reviews.Content: Terrific place to stay if you want to spend time at the Vatican. Very quiet location. Rooms were very small...even by Europe standards. Shower was extremely small. Wifi was just OK. Excellent breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Close to Vatican”
Reviews.Author: fhille
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 3 nights in a double room. The main reason to stay at this hotel is the proximity to the Vatican. The double room was quite small but comfortable. A couple of luggage racks for our suitcases would have made the smaller space easier to cope with. The bathroom was ok but would have been better if it had an extractor fan - we swtiched on the air conditioning to cope with the humidity from the shower. There is a hair dryer in the bathroom which works well enough but if you are used to a powerful salon hair dryer, you may want to bring your own. The bedding and towels were all high quality and the rooms were cleaned every day. The breakfast had lots of choices including cooked eggs and bacon as well as the usual continental options. The price of this hotel reflects the location more than the facilities. It is very special to be able to look out of your window and see St Peter's Basilica. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The daily Mass readings were a nice touch as a Roman Catholic. This would be an especially good choice for those who are visiting who want to see the Vatican but aren't able to walk for long distances as you literally walk out the door and St Peter's Square is across the street.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven on Earth”
Reviews.Author: Arizona_Ron
Reviews.Content: This was my 3rd stay at Paolo VI in one year. Stefanie, Laura, Nicoletta are the best in front office help. The view of St. Peter's is spell binding. The helpfulness of the staff is beyond compare in Rome. The location is perfect for touring not only St. Peter's, but also having access to all the tour routes in Rome. The restaurant is perfect. The Breakfast's are huge and Pierra and the staff are so very helpful. We stay at Paolo VI not only because you can see St. Peter's and the Pope's Apartments from the terrace, but also because the staff is so excellent. I give this hotel a 5 star rating. I have stayed there for over 30 nights in the past year.

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable stay right next to St Peters/Vatican”
Reviews.Author: CATraveler30s
Reviews.Content: We had a nice stay with good service and traditional European breakfast. Since we were there only for 2 nights (on the way to Amalfi Coast), I think we could have found something better near the Termini station at a better value (we paid 170 euros a night for a double). Pros: Right next to the Vatican/St Peters Basilica if that is your focus of the visit, clean rooms, friendly service! Cons: Rooms were quite small, bed not that comfortable In a nutshell, would recommend Residencia for anyone looking to be in/near the Vatican and looking for a nice, simple room.

Reviews.Title: “A lovely little Hotel”
Reviews.Author: HelenWestYorkshire
Reviews.Content: We have recently returned from Rome where we stayed for 3 nights.We were very pleased with our choice of Hotel although the bedroom was on the small side for 2 people. We found the hotel very quiet in the night which was a real bonus.The position is excellent so handy for the city Tour buses at the other end of the square. Plenty of small eating places around but by early evening many are closing up.The hotel breakfast more than adequate and the staff extremely helpful at all times. The sheets and towels were changed daily and of very good quality. The shower was excellent with plenty of hot water. If you are booking this Hotel they offer a Airport pick up service which we did not use initially.Having been given a quote of 75E for the trip to the hotel by a taxi driver we caught the city transfer bus from the airport which was 8E each but when we got to Central Rome and got a taxi and were charged 40E and driven by a mad man through Rome neither of us being shrinking violets but we were both terrified and glad to get out. For our return to the Airport we booked the Hotel transport, a very smooth ride costing 50E wish we had done that in the 1st place.

Reviews.Title: “great location”
Reviews.Author: mbb1947
Reviews.Content: My husband and I enjoyed our stay at the hotel. Hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. Location is great. We were able to walk to other attractions but was nice to escape the crowds at the other tourist locations. The view from the terrace was beautiful and a great place to enjoy a glass of wine in the evening.

Reviews.Title: “Good location, value, very nice, and accomodating staff.”
Reviews.Author: CruiserNyc
Reviews.Content: We stayed pre-cruise for 2 days, & the breakfast and rooms were nice. The locaction is greant b/c it is near transportation. (bus lines, commuter lines to get to the port in Civitavecchia, about and hour away, and metro, we are from NYC, so we are walkers, and enjoyed the excercise after many Italian sumptous meals. The rooms are quiet, clean and comfortable. The staff was very helpful w/ restaurant, sight-seeing, and transportation suggestions. I would recommend this hotel and stay there again, when I revisit Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable, central & welcoming”
Reviews.Author: mrjohnsondog
Reviews.Content: A solo traveller (although meeting friends in Rome), this was a superb central spot; opposite St Peters Square with fantastic views of the dome at night. Rooms were small (but I was a single) and a little noisy, but nothing that a pair of earplugs couldn't put right. Clean and well equipped with a lovely little "daily prayer" posted through your door each morning as the hotel is owned by Vatican Accommodations it is mainly (but by no means exclusively) frequented by priests and their families. Lovely choice at breakfast time and a cracking roof top terrace. I'd stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Very pleased”
Reviews.Author: characterisdestiny
Reviews.Content: I took my 3 daughters. We booked 2 rooms. I was very pleased. You walk across the street and you are in St. Peter's Square. This is great because the nearest Metro stop is 6 blocks away. The breakfast was very good. But I most liked the staff. They were very friendly and kind to me and my 3 daughters. Are the rooms small? Most European hotel rooms are small. We went to Italy to spend as little time in our hotel as possible. They have a balcony that overlooks the square and some older couples dined there, but my 3 kids needed something less serene.

Reviews.Title: “racism at Paolo VI”
Reviews.Author: dyebob
Reviews.Content: the staff of this hotel insulted my wife for being non-white and non catholic. It ruined an otherwise lovely trip to Italy.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, Elegant Hotel with a great location”
Reviews.Author: BMazz
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Residenza Paolo VI in Rome on Feb. 18-19th, 2008. It was recommended to us by a business partner/friend who lives in Italy who stays there when in Rome on business. Once it was recommended I looked it up on TripAdvisor, and was dismayed at some of the reviews. First, the location; walk out the front entranceway and take twenty steps across a street and you are in St Peter's Square. Wonderful! The location was quiet, and we slept with our windows open without a noise problem. The hotel is not its own building; it shares a building with an embassy.. the hotel is on the third floor, and there is an elevator. The street entrance is a very nice small piazza, and the entrance door is locked and you must ring to be buzzed in. There are plenty of nice restaurants and shops within easy walking distance. The room: We did call to request a deluxe room after I saw some of the pictures of the room sizes. We were given Room 108, and we were VERY pleased. It was actually, to me, a small suite! It had two twin beds pushed together, a nice sitting area, and a nicely appointed although small bathroom. It was nicely decorated, the windows were tall and narrow and easy to open. The bathroom is a typical European bathroom; toilet and bidet, a small single sink with limited shelf space, a hairdryer that worked well, and a small tub with a handheld shower hooked to the wall. There was plenty of water pressure and hot water. For people making their way in Europe for the first time the bathrooms are most likely a shock as they are not American in any way. I personally like the difference, and I like the addition of a bidet. I don't spend a lot of time in the shower so the size isn't important. The beds were very comfortable and the linens very nice. The mini-bar in the room was well stocked with sodas, wines, beer, cognac, whiskey, and some small snacks. Room service was available from 4:00pm until 11:00pm. Breakfast was the usual European buffet... eggs, prosciutto, fruit, cheese, croissant, yogurt, coffee, tea, wine. We had a late night snack of minestrone, prosciutto, melon, cheese one evening that was very good. The hotel was furnished very elegantly, and the staff was professional, courteous and friendly. The breakfast room upstairs (there is an elevator) is very nice, and the views off the terrace are magnificent... you look right into St Peter's Square at the Cathedral. The price is right for the location; right on top of Vatican City. I think in fact it is quite reasonable for the quality of service and presentation afforded. This is Europe, and not America. I can see from some of the reviews that an unfair comparison is made because of this. I, for one, enjoy the differences I experience while in Europe... please feel free to contact me if you would like further information about the hotel or the area. I recommend this hotel with 100% confidence.

Reviews.Title: “the best”
Reviews.Author: moviegal3
Reviews.Content: Wonderful location, delightful service. Have zero complaints.

Reviews.Title: “You can't get any closer!”
Reviews.Author: day1420
Reviews.Content: I would highly recommend this hotel for it's amazing location just yards from St. Peter's square, helpful and polite staff, large beds (which is hard to find in Rome!), and absolutely beautiful view of St. Peter's dome from the hotel's roof deck. The afternoon we arrived in Rome, (after our flight was delayed from NYC 3 hours) would have been our only opportunity to see the Vatican museum including the Sistine Chapel; and had it not been for the hotel's prime location there is no way we would have made it in. As for distances to attractions....St. Peters Square is literally across the street; it's about a 5 minute walk to the Vatican Museum entrance (minus time waiting on the long line); and less than 15 min walk to Castel St. Angelo. We stayed on this side of the city 1 night before a cruise, and on the other side of the city closer to the Colusseun for 1 night after our cruise. Best experience ever!

Reviews.Title: “Peter, I can see your house from here”
Reviews.Author: coolinshot
Reviews.Content: I proposed to my girlfriend (now my wife) from the sun terrace of this lovely hotel. It was a cloudless May evening and I had lured her onto the terrace for a late glass of wine. I couldn't have chosen a more romantic setting and as you can guess it went well. The hotel couldn't be any closer to the St Peter's Piazza and if you are feeling fit you are in walking distance of most of the sites in Rome (I had swollen, bleeding feet after 4 days but it was well worth it). The staff at the hotel are very friendly and polite (more than you can say for most "Romans" and I don't mean that as an insult but they are famous for it and boy do they live up to the stereotype). We arranged for the hotel's car to pick us up and there it was on our arrival to Rome - no waiting around - a very polite driver waiting to take us to the hotel in style (not inexpensive but I think it was well worth the money). As the driver turned into the narrow City streets I felt as though I had just passed through a time portal - the sense of history and the grandiosity of St. Peters is awe inspiring. The room in the hotel was very small (we didn't have a deluxe) but it was clean, well furnished and comfortable. After all, you don't go to Rome to stay in your room. I would definitely stay at this hotel again and fully intend to as soon as my feet return to their normal size Col

Reviews.Title: “Great little place - but read on...”
Reviews.Author: entshop
Reviews.Content: Here is the deal. Read all the reviews, note that the good ones are from folks who stayed in the larger rooms. I believe that the biggest problem is that the small rooms are REALLY small. The website suggests a bit more elbow room than actually exists. We stayed in a deluxe suite, with our (older) kids in a triple. The front desk staff was pleasant and helpful. The dining staff may not have been outgoing, but the area was clean, and they accomodated us (arriving late one day, leaving early the next). I don't know how often the larger balcony is open, but they opened it for the Christmas address (wonderful) and the manager even let us out for a night photo with St Peter's dome in the background while we were dressed after Midnight Mass (nearly three AM). If the floorplan suits your needs, the staff and location are certainly a plus!

Reviews.Title: “The only place I will stay in Rome from now on”
Reviews.Author: CatherineNY
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a stay at the Residenza Paolo VI, and will never stay anywhere else in Rome. I gather from some of the reviews and photos that I was fortunate to have a deluxe room, which was comfortable, beautiful, quiet, and spotless. It had a marble floor, and a couple of lovely oriental rugs; damask drapes; and simple, but attractive, furniture. There were casement windows -- a delightful contrast to the sealed-in windows in typical modern hotels. I cannot speak for the other rooms in the hotel, but my experience was delightful. The front desk staff was incredibly helpful and charming. I felt safe (the front door is locked in the evening), and the location -- just off one side of Piazza San Pietro -- was incredible. We strolled right from breakfast over to the papal audience in front of St. Peter's. The breakfast room is particularly beautiful, and the buffet breakfast was ample and delicious. Service in the breakfast room was pleasant, but on the relaxed side. Not a big problem, as the more impatient among us could just walk a few feet and pour ourselves a cup of coffee. The view from the terrace is matchless. There are a lot of good restaurants in the area, and a taxi stand right across the square. I recommend the hotel very, very highly, and I am a frequent business traveller with high standards.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the Money”
Reviews.Author: FERNGT3
Reviews.Content: Do not be taken in by the great marketing for this hotel, pity it doesnt live up to it. Overpriced, rooms tiny, air conditioning poor, lift archaic, terrace tiny, appears on photos much better than it actually is. I suggest you look elsewhere unless you absolutely must be about 500yds from St Peters Square. Breakfast is OK. Staff helpfull

Reviews.Title: “TINY tiny teeny-tiny rooms - 2 star hotel”
Reviews.Author: snooky
Reviews.Content: Stayed here in mid-May in a 'twin room' accompanying an elderly 79 year old neighbour of mine whose long held wish was to see the Vatican and also Pope John Paul II's tomb. As this lady hasn't travelled since 1965 & has had a lot of illness recently, I chose the hotel on the basis that she would be able to see St. Peter's/Vatican from the hotel, AND have a nice looking hotel room - after all, the pictures of the rooms looked fine enough on the Residenzia Paolo site, and though not outstanding, I felt coupled with the location it would be a good balance. I was very VERY sorely dissapointed, no so much for myself as I travel a lot, but for the elderly lady who was so looking forward to her big once in a lifetime trip - This has to be THE tiniest room I have ever had the displeasure of staying in. The rooms are in my view around 2 star quality, and as the previous reviewer noted, the rooms show online are of the 2 suites that they have. Also it should be noted that this 'hotel' occupies the 3rd - 5th floor of a building, not the whole building. There is no 'concierge' to greet you at the door as shown online either - a small lane with a privately run gift shop on the left leads up to a nondescript door, and a chronically slow lift/elevator takes you to the 3rd floor hotel. At 270 euro a night you can see from my pictures what you get for your money - not enough room to swing the proverbial cat. The furniture, what little there is of it, is a dull looking utilitarian affair. When we 'separated' the 'twin' beds by 6 inches so that we could at least have the pretence of a twin room, I couldn't even open the wardrobe. The safe in our wardrobe didn't work. The minibar was did work however - and at 5 euro the one solitary mini bottle of red wine was consumed between us to drown our sorrows - there was some stronger stuff in there, but we had a long day ahead of us and as I said, my friend isn't in her prime anymore! The bathroom is virtually in the sleeping area - so you can hear all the comings and goings of your room mate inside the toilet whilst you watch the tiny tv - (only CNN and an Asian channel in English by the way). Most unpleasant. The bathroom is minute (surprise!) and again utilitarian with white tiles . They did supply the usual soaps/shower caps etc, but there's nowhere to store any of your own toiletries & it only contains a shower (no bath). There is no dressing table in the bedroom so if you were thinking of going out on the town, you'd have to do your preening in front of the mirror in the tiny bathroom. There is a hair dryer placed in a holder above the bidet (the mind boggles). The one bedroom window is impossible to see out of - very prison like - unless you jump up and hang on like an escapee you won't be looking out of the window at all. I did complain to a member of staff that I thought the room very small, but they said they were all the same being as it was a former monastery. I did look in at other rooms and they did have the same 'inmate' type appearance. You cannot go out onto the much vaunted terrace as someone else has noted - but to be fair you can see the top of St. Peter's, and at night it's quite a nice view (see pic) - but only a few seats (about 5 tables or so), so hopefully everyone in the 26 rooms won't want to sit at the side of the terrace at once. The breakfast was again 2 star. The service was very inattentive. There were two waitresses on duty when we arrived, & neither were serving anyone. Even though they saw us seat ourselves down, they carried on cleaning breakfast bits and pieces and ignoring us. Eventually I had to call one over to order tea. Later I asked one of them for some pepper - and after some 5 minutes I didn't get it, so I got up and got it myself from another couple at another table. The scrambled egg was cold and the bacon looked burnt. The toaster didn't do much toasting. The tea was ok though. There was also the usual cold selection of various cereals/yoghurts and so on. Back to the lift/elevator topic - there are two lifts - one to get to the hotel on the 3rd floor, and one for those who cannot climb stairs within the hotel to get to the next 2 floors. As I said, the lift to get to the hotel is chronically slow, but the interior lift is terminally ill. You have to press the lift button continuously to call the lift, and once inside the lift press your floor button continuously to get to your destination (you cannot take your finger off the button else it stops!!!!)....and it's slow... slow - SLOW - you wonder if you'll ever get out of there - and muse that perhaps you are in purgatory!. If they had advertised the true state of the rooms I wouldn't have minded QUITE so much, and my singular mark for them has been influenced by the deception that the rooms are so much better than they are, else I would have given them 2 marks. This isn't a hotel in my view - it's a guest house and they should jolly well say so. Really - my advice is don't bother with this hotel unless you really HAVE to be this close to St. Peter's/Vatican. The rooms in this hotel really only serve the true 'monks' amongst us!.

Reviews.Title: “Not as marketed on websites”
Reviews.Author: Conoula
Reviews.Content: I decided to plan a 3-day trip to Rome through the internet. Unfortunately, despite its great quiet location (especially when one wants to visit the Vatican), the hotel disappointed me mainly because in most websites Residenza Paolo VI is presented as a luxury premier hotel. As you can see from the picture - this is not what people would describe as luxury! I was so disappointed when I arrived that I had to take a picture of the room! Its size was the size of a typical bathroom in other hotels! The bathroom was ok for one person, although very plain with just the basics. Of course in the hotel's web site they show their suite in the photos... The cost for this single room in the photo was 192 euros per night (low season). I thought that because I was travelling alone, they gave me one of their worst rooms for single use. When I returned and read the other reviews, I realised that apparently all rooms except the suites are in the same condition. Also, you could not see the promised view from their so much promoted veranda, neither could you see anything from the room window, which was located above my head (I am 167 cm tall) and I had to step on the bed to see outside! The hotel personnel was very helpful and nice and breakfast was great. It was fortunate that I only stayed 3 days.. and thank God Rome is such a wonderful and blessed city, with so many things to see and places to go! [In Greece, you can stay at the Grande Bretagne, the most luxurious hotel in Athens with full amenities located in the centre of Athens with view of the Acropolis, with only 240 euros in the low season!]

Reviews.Title: “Great location, odd hotel”
Reviews.Author: free101girl
Reviews.Content: If you are planning to visit the Vatican museums, Sistine Chapel and/or St. Peter's, you absolutely cannot stay any closer. The Paolo VI is literally across the street from the exit of Piazza San Pietro (St. Peter's Square). When we finished our exhausting and hot, but very worthwhile tour of the Vatican museums and Sistine Chapel, we literally walked out the exit, crossed the street and were in our room with our feet up within 5 minutes. However, this is a very expensive hotel with few amenities. We paid EUR340 for one night in a Deluxe room, including buffet breakfast and tax. (By the way, a Deluxe room is not the cheapest room. I believe the cheapest room was around EUR300.) Our room was totally charmless. It reminded me of a room in a well-maintained retirement home. The floor was light-colored marble, with three inexpensive "Oriental" throw rugs scattered about. The room's cherry furnishings were very plain -- obviously new but not particularly high-end. The only room decor consisted of two framed black-and-white prints of ancient monuments and a funereal-looking plastic flower arrangement. The only "luxurious" elements were the fabrics used in the drapes and bedspreads, which were obviously high-quality but not particularly attractive. The overall effect was cold and spartan -- I felt you could almost clean the room by hosing it down. The air conditioning was excellent. The bathroom was large and completely tiled in glaring white for that oh-so-warm mortuary look. It was more or less disabled-accessible, with a raised toilet and roll-in shower (no grab bars, though), which we had not requested but didn't mind. Amenities (soap, etc) were minimal and not very nice. What irritates me is that the room shown in their marketing materials looks NOTHING like the room we were assigned. While I realize all hotels tend to use their nicest suites for promotional photography, usually the decor bears at least some resemblance to a standard room in the hotel. Not so here! Another disappointment is the terrace, which is pictured on the hotel web site. It does indeed look like the photos. What isn't clear, however, is that the seating area is well back from the edge of the terrace (like 40 feet), and you aren't allowed outside of the seating area, which has a fence around it. From that vantage point can't see any of the (no doubt fabulous) view, except for the very top of the colonnades around the piazza and the clocks at the top of the church. I don't know why the restriction -- perhaps it's a security issue since the Pope frequently appears in the piazza? Whatever the case, while the terrace is beautiful, it was frustrating to sit where you couldn't really see anything! Additionally, the hotel's web site and literature says it has a "restaurant." This is not true. There is a very attractively decorated breakfast room on the top floor that serves an extensive continental breakfast buffet each morning. (The food was good quality, with plenty of choices.) There are also sandwiches available for purchase during limited hours, which they will serve you on the terrace. That's it. No actual meals, no room service. The rooms have minibars and there is bar service on the terrace during limited hours. Both the minibar and bar service had very low prices for Rome -- around EUR5 for a glass of wine or beer, which is less than half what you normally pay at 4 and 5-star hotels in Italy. Bible verses are slipped under the door of your room each morning. By the way, the main clientele at the Paolo VI seemed to be priests and nuns. Are they also paying EUR300+ a night to stay there? I find it hard to believe. In short, despite the marketing hype, don't expect a luxury hotel. It's more like an overpriced bed and breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Exceptional!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: If you want to stay near the Vatican and if you want to feel special, this is the place to stay. The staff is very helpful in everything from finding a restaurant to coaching on how to use the Metro and bus system. Little touches include delivering the daily Mass readings each morning and recognizing special feast days. Great full 'American' breakfast. Look across the Piazza San Pietro and see the Pope deliver his Sunday blessing.
